Chapter 11, Part 6: The Bodhisattva Lion's Roar
The Bodhisattva Lion's Roar said:
World-Honored One!

If all karmas do not necessarily bring about results, and if all sentient beings possess buddha-nature and should cultivate the eightfold noble path, then why is it that all sentient beings do not attain this great parinirvÄá¹‡a?
World-Honored One!
If all sentient beings possess buddha-nature, then they should definitely attain supreme, perfect enlightenment. Why is it necessary to cultivate the eightfold noble path?
World-Honored One!
In this sÅ«tra, it is said that a sick person, if they obtain medicine, a nurse, and proper food and drink according to their illness, will be cured whether or not they do so.
All sentient beings are also like this. If they encounter Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, buddhas, bodhisattvas, and good and virtuous friends, and hear the Dharma and cultivate the noble path,
If they do not encounter, hear, or cultivate the path, they will all attain supreme, perfect enlightenment.
Why is this?
Because of buddha-nature.
World-Honored One!

It is like the sun and moon, which no one can block from reaching the edge of the Aá¸a mountain, or the waters of the four great rivers from reaching the great ocean, or icchantikas from going to hell.
All sentient beings are also like this. No one can block them from reaching supreme, perfect enlightenment.
Why is this?
Because of buddha-nature.
World-Honored One!

For this reason, all sentient beings do not need to cultivate the path. Because of the power of buddha-nature, they should attain supreme, perfect enlightenment, not because of cultivating the power of the holy path.
World-Honored One!
If icchantikas, those who commit the four grave offenses, and those who commit the five heinous crimes cannot attain supreme perfect enlightenment, then they should definitely cultivate.
Because they will definitely attain it due to buddha-nature, it is not that they attain it only after cultivation.
World-Honored One!
It is like a magnet, even if far from iron, due to its power, the iron is attracted.
The buddha-nature of sentient beings is also like this, therefore they do not need to diligently cultivate the path.
The Buddha said:
Excellent, excellent!
Good man!
On the banks of the Ganges there are seven kinds of people. If they want to bathe, fear bandits, or pick flowers, they enter the river.
The first person enters the water and sinks.
Why is it so?
Because they are weak and powerless, and are not used to floating.
The second person, although sinking, returns to the surface, and after surfacing, sinks again.
Why is it so?
Because of the great power of the body, he can come back up, but because he is not used to floating, he sinks again after coming up.
The third person sinks and then comes up, and after coming up, he does not sink again.
Why is this?
Because he is heavy, he sinks, but because he has great power, he comes up. Because he is used to floating, after coming up, he immediately stays still.
The fourth person enters and then sinks, and after sinking, he comes back up. After coming up, he immediately stays still and looks around in all directions.
Why is this?

Because he is heavy, he sinks, but because he has great power, he comes back up. Because he is used to floating, he stays still. Because he does not know where to come out from, he looks around in all directions.

The fifth person enters and immediately sinks, and after sinking, he comes up. After coming up, he immediately stays still. After staying still, he looks around. After looking around, he immediately leaves.
Why is this?
Because he is afraid.
The sixth person enters and immediately leaves, and when he reaches shallow water, he stays still.
Why is this?
Because he is looking to see how far away the bandits are.
The seventh person, having reached the other shore, ascended a great mountain, was no longer afraid, was free from all enemies, and experienced great happiness.
Good man!

The great river of birth and death is also like this. There are seven kinds of people who, fearing the enemies of afflictions, wish to cross the great river of birth and death, leave the household life, shave their heads, and wear the Dharma robes.

Having left the household life, they associate with bad friends, follow their teachings, and listen to and accept wrong teachings, which say that the body of sentient beings is the five aggregates, and the five aggregates are called the five great elements. If sentient beings die, they permanently sever the five great elements. Since they sever the five great elements, why is it necessary to cultivate good and evil karma? Therefore, they should know that there is no good or evil, or retribution for good and evil.
This is called icchantika.
Icchantika means severing wholesome roots. Because they sever wholesome roots, they sink in the river of birth and death and cannot escape.
Why is it so?
Because of the heaviness of evil karma and the lack of the power of faith, like the first person by the Ganges River.
Good son, there are six reasons why the icchantikas sink in the three evil paths and cannot escape.
What are the six?

First, because their evil mind is rampant; second, because they do not see the afterlife; third, because they enjoy cultivating afflictions; fourth, because they are far from the roots of goodness; fifth, because evil karma obstructs them; sixth, because they associate with evil friends.
There are also five things that cause one to sink in the three evil paths.
What are the five?

First, because they do non-dharma on the side of monks; second, because they do non-dharma on the side of nuns; third, because they freely use the Sangha's possessions; fourth, because they do non-dharma on the side of their mothers; fifth, because they create right and wrong among the five parts of the Sangha.
There are also five things that cause one to sink in the three evil paths.
What are the five?

First, they always say there are no good or bad karmic fruits; second, they kill sentient beings who have given rise to the aspiration for enlightenment; third, they delight in speaking of the faults of Dharma teachers; fourth, they say what is not Dharma is Dharma and what is Dharma is not Dharma; fifth, they listen and accept with the intention of seeking faults in the Dharma.
There are also three things that cause one to sink into the three evil paths.
What are the three?

First, saying the TathÄgata is impermanent and eternally extinguished; second, saying the true Dharma is impermanent and changes; third, saying the Sangha can be destroyed. Therefore, one always sinks into the three evil paths.
As for the second person, they give rise to the intention to cross the great river of birth and death, but because they have severed the roots of goodness, they sink and cannot emerge.
What is meant by emerging is to draw close to good friends and thus attain faith.

This faith is faith in giving and the fruits of giving, faith in goodness and the fruits of goodness, faith in evil and the fruits of evil, faith in birth, death, suffering, impermanence, and destruction. This is called faith.
Having attained faith, they cultivate pure precepts, uphold and recite, copy and explain the scriptures, and are always happy to give and skillfully cultivate wisdom.
However, due to dull faculties, they encounter bad friends again and are unable to cultivate body, precepts, mind, and wisdom, and listen to and accept deviant teachings;
Or they encounter bad times and live in bad countries, cutting off all wholesome roots.
Because of cutting off wholesome roots, they are always submerged in birth and death, like the second person on the bank of the Ganges.

The third person is one who wishes to cross the great river of birth and death, but because they have cut off wholesome roots they sink in it. Associating with good friends is called emerging, and having faith in the TathÄgata as being omniscient, constant and unchanging, teaching the unsurpassed path for the sake of sentient beings, all sentient beings having buddha-nature, the TathÄgata not being extinguished, the Dharma and Sangha also being so, without destruction.
The icchantikas and others do not cut off this Dharma, and in the end they cannot attain supreme, perfect enlightenment. They must distance themselves from it and then they will attain it.

Because of their faith, they cultivate pure precepts. Having cultivated the precepts, they uphold, recite, copy, and explain the twelve divisions of the canon, widely propagating it for the sake of sentient beings. They delight in giving and cultivate wisdom. Because of their sharp faculties, they firmly abide in faith and wisdom, their minds without regression, like the third person on the banks of the Ganges.

The fourth person is one who has the intention to cross the great river of birth and death, but due to severing the roots of goodness, they sink in the middle. Because they associate with good friends, they attain faith. This is called emerging. Because they attain faith, they uphold, recite, copy, and explain the twelve divisions of the canon. For the sake of sentient beings, they widely propagate and spread [the Dharma]. They enjoy giving and cultivate wisdom. Because of their sharp faculties, they firmly abide in faith and wisdom, their mind without regression. They survey the four directions. Surveying the four directions refers to the four fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a, like the fourth person on the bank of the Ganges River.

As for the fifth person, he is one who wishes to cross the great river of birth and death, but because he has severed the roots of goodness he sinks in the middle. Because he associates with good friends, he gains faith. This is called emerging. Because of faith, he upholds, recites, copies, and explains the twelve divisions of the canon. For the sake of sentient beings, he widely disseminates and spreads [the Dharma]. He delights in giving wisdom and cultivates wisdom. Because of his sharp faculties, he firmly abides in faith and wisdom, his mind without turning back. Having no turning back, he then advances. 'Advancing' refers to pratyekabuddhas. Although they are able to cross over themselves, they do not reach sentient beings. This is called 'going,' like the fifth person on the banks of the Ganges.

The sixth person is one who has the intention to cross the great river of birth and death, but due to severing the roots of goodness, they sink in the middle. Relying on good friends, they attain faith. Because of having faith, they are called 'emerged'. Because of faith, they uphold, recite, copy, and explain the twelve divisions of the canon. For the sake of sentient beings, they widely propagate and spread [the Dharma]. They delight in giving and cultivate wisdom. Because of their sharp faculties, they firmly abide in faith and wisdom, with no turning back. Having no turning back, they then proceed further and finally reach the shallows. Having reached the shallows, they then stay and do not go any further. Those who stay and do not go are the bodhisattvas. In order to liberate all sentient beings, they stay and contemplate the afflictions, like the sixth person on the bank of the Ganges River.

The seventh person is one who has the intention to cross the great river of birth and death, but because they have severed their wholesome roots they sink in the middle. Associating with good friends, they attain faith. Having attained faith, this is called emerging. Because of faith, they uphold, recite, copy, and explain the twelve divisions of the scriptures. For the sake of sentient beings, they widely propagate and spread them, delight in giving, and cultivate wisdom. Because of their sharp faculties, they firmly abide in faith and wisdom, their minds without regression. Without regression, they then move forward. Having moved forward, they reach the other shore and ascend a great mountain, free from all fears and experiencing much peace and happiness.
Good man!
The mountain on the other shore is a metaphor for the TathÄgata. Experiencing peace and happiness is a metaphor for the Buddha's eternal abiding. The great mountain is a metaphor for great nirvÄá¹‡a.
Good man!
These people on the banks of the Ganges all have hands and feet but are unable to cross.

All sentient beings are also like this. They truly possess the Buddha Jewel, Dharma Jewel, and Sangha Jewel. The TathÄgata always expounds the essential meaning of the Dharma, the Eightfold Noble Path, and the great parinirvÄá¹‡a, but all sentient beings are unable to attain it.
This is not my fault, nor is it the fault of the noble path or sentient beings.
One should know that it is all due to the evil of afflictions. For this reason, all sentient beings are unable to attain nirvÄá¹‡a.
Good man!
It is like a skilled doctor who knows the illness and prescribes medicine, but the patient does not take it. It is not the fault of the doctor.
Good man!
It is like a donor who gives all his possessions to everyone, but there are those who do not accept it. It is not the fault of the donor.
Good man!
It is like when the sun rises, illuminating all darkness, but blind people do not see the road. It is not the fault of the sun.
Good man!
The water of the Ganges River can quench thirst, but those who are thirsty do not drink it. It is not the fault of the water.
Good man!
It is like the great earth, universally producing fruits and grains, equally without duality. If farmers do not plant, it is not the fault of the earth.
Good man!
The TathÄgata universally and extensively opens up the twelve divisions of the scriptures for all sentient beings, but if sentient beings do not accept them, it is not the fault of the TathÄgata.
Good man!
If one cultivates the path, one will attain supreme, perfect enlightenment.
Good man!
You say that since all sentient beings have buddha-nature, they should attain supreme, perfect enlightenment, like a magnet.
Excellent, excellent!
Because of the power of the cause of buddha-nature, one attains supreme, perfect enlightenment;
if you say that one does not need to cultivate the holy path, that is not so.
Good man!
It is like a person walking through a wilderness, thirsty and exhausted, encountering a well. The well is deep and dark, although one cannot see the water, one should know that it must exist.
This person skillfully seeks out a bucket and rope, and when they draw water, they will see it.
The buddha-nature is also like this. Although all sentient beings possess it, they must cultivate the uncontaminated holy path before they can see it.
Good man!
If there is sesame, then one can see oil. Apart from skillful means, one cannot see it. Sugarcane is also like this.
Good man!
Like the Thirty-three Celestials and Uttarakuru, although they are existent dharmas, if one does not have wholesome karma or the spiritual power of the path, then one cannot see them.
Because the earth covers it, sentient beings cannot see the grass roots in the ground and the water under the ground.
The buddha-nature is also like this. Because one does not cultivate the holy path, one cannot see it.
Good man!

As you have said, there are sick people in the world who, if they encounter a nurse, a good doctor, good medicine, and food and drink suitable for their illness, or even if they do not encounter them, can all be cured.
Good man!
I speak this meaning for the bodhisattvas of the sixth stage.
Good sons!

It is like space, which is neither internal nor external to sentient beings, and because it is neither internal nor external, it is also unobstructed. The Buddha-nature of sentient beings is also like this.
Good sons!
It is like a person whose wealth is in another place. Although it is not present before them, they can use it as they wish. When someone asks about it, they say, I own it.
Why is it so?
Because it definitely exists.
The Buddha-nature of sentient beings is also like this. It is neither here nor there, and because it can definitely be attained, it is said to exist in all.
Good sons!
It is like sentient beings creating various karmas, whether good or evil, which are neither internal nor external.

Such karmic natures are neither existent nor nonexistent, and they are also not originally nonexistent and now existent, not produced without a cause, not created here and experienced here, not created here and experienced there, not created there and experienced there;
There is no doer and no receiver, but the combination of time and conditions results in karmic retribution.

The buddha-nature of sentient beings is also like this. It is neither originally nonexistent nor existent now, neither internal nor external, neither existent nor nonexistent, neither here nor there, not coming from elsewhere, not without causes and conditions, and not unseen by all sentient beings. There are bodhisattvas who, when the causes and conditions come together, can see it.

As for the time, it refers to the bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas of the ten abodes who cultivate the eightfold noble path and attain an impartial mind towards all sentient beings. At that time, they can see it, but it is not called creation.
Good man!
Your statement about the lodestone is not correct.
Why is it so?
The stone does not attract the iron.
Why is it so?
Because it has no mental activity.
Good man!
Because different dharmas exist, different dharmas are born. Because different dharmas do not exist, different dharmas are destroyed. There is no creator and no destroyer.
Good man!
It is like a raging fire that cannot burn firewood, but when the fire comes out and the firewood is destroyed, it is called burning firewood.
Good man!
It is like a sunflower that turns to follow the sun, but this sunflower has no reverence, no consciousness, and no karma, because of the nature of different dharmas it turns by itself.
Good man!

It is like a banana tree that grows in response to thunder. This tree has no ears, no mind, no intention, and no consciousness. Because of the existence of different dharmas, different dharmas grow. Because of the absence of different dharmas, different dharmas are destroyed.
Good man!

It is like an aÅ›oka tree. When a woman touches it, flowers appear. This tree has no mind, no awareness, and no touch. Because of the existence of different dharmas, different dharmas arise. Because of the absence of different dharmas, different dharmas are destroyed.
Good man!

It is like an orange tree that bears abundant fruit when fertilized with corpses. This orange tree has no mind and no touch. Because of the existence of different dharmas, different dharmas flourish. Because of the absence of different dharmas, different dharmas are destroyed.
Good man!

Just as the pomegranate tree bears abundant fruit due to bricks, bones, and manure, the pomegranate tree also has no mind to contact. Because of the existence of different dharmas, different dharmas are born. Because of the absence of different dharmas, different dharmas are destroyed.
Good man!

The attraction of iron by the lodestone is also like this. Because of the existence of different dharmas, different dharmas are born. Because of the absence of different dharmas, different dharmas are destroyed.
The buddha-nature of sentient beings is also like this. It cannot attract anuttarÄ-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi.
Good man!

Ignorance cannot attract formations, and formations also cannot attract consciousness. It can still be called ignorance as a condition for formations, and formations as a condition for consciousness. Whether there are buddhas or not, the dharma realm is always abiding.
Good man!
If it is said that buddha-nature abides within sentient beings,
good man!
The dharma of permanence has no abode. If there is a place of abiding, it is impermanent.
Good man!
Just as the twelve links of dependent origination have no fixed abode, if they had an abode, the twelve links of dependent origination could not be called permanent.
The Tathagata's Dharma body also has no abode. The Dharma realm, Dharma entrance, Dharma aggregate, and space all have no abode.
Buddha-nature is also like this, with no abode at all.
Good man!

It is like the four great elements, although their power is equal, some are solid, some are hot, some are wet, some are moving, some are heavy, some are light, some are red, some are white, some are yellow, some are black, but these four great elements also have no karma, because they are different from the Dharma realm, each is not similar.
Buddha-nature is also like this, because it is different from the Dharma realm, when the time comes it manifests.
Good man!

Because all sentient beings do not regress from buddha-nature, it is called having. Because of irreversibility, because of future existence, because of definite attainment, because of definite seeing, therefore it is called all sentient beings have buddha-nature.
Good man!
It is like a king who tells a great minister, 'You lead an elephant and show it to the blind.'
At that time, the great minister, having received the king's order, gathers many blind people and shows them the elephant.
The many blind people each touch it with their hands. The great minister then returns and says to the king, 'I have already shown it.'
At that time, the great king immediately calls the many blind people and asks them, 'Have you seen the elephant?'
The many blind people each say, 'We have already seen it.'
The king says, 'What is the elephant like?'ğŸ”½Those who touch its tusks say the elephant's form is like a radish root;
those who touch its ears say the elephant is like a winnowing basket;ğŸ”½those who touch its head say the elephant is like a stone;
those who touch its trunk say the elephant is like a pestle;ğŸ”½those who touch its legs say the elephant is like a wooden mortar;
those who touch its back say the elephant is like a bed;
Those who touched its belly said the elephant was like a jar;
Those who touched its tail said the elephant was like a rope.
Good man!
Like those blind people, they did not describe the elephant's body, nor did they not describe it.
If none of those characteristics were an elephant, apart from them there would be no separate elephant.
Good man!

The king is a metaphor for the TathÄgata's perfect knowledge, the minister is a metaphor for the MahÄparinirvÄá¹‡a SÅ«tra, the elephant is a metaphor for buddha-nature, and the blind are a metaphor for all ignorant beings.
When these beings hear the Buddha's teaching, some say:
'Form is buddha-nature.
Why is it so?
Because although form ceases, it continues in succession, and therefore one attains the TathÄgata's thirty-two marks.
The TathÄgata's form is permanent, because the TathÄgata's form is uninterrupted. Therefore form is called buddha-nature.

It is like true gold, although its substance changes, its color always remains the same. Sometimes it is made into bracelets, sometimes into hairpins, sometimes into bowls, but its yellow color never changes.
The Buddha-nature of sentient beings is also like this. Although its substance is impermanent, its color is permanent. For this reason, it is said that form is the Buddha-nature.
Some say:
'Feeling is the Buddha-nature.
Why is it so?
Because of feeling, one attains the true bliss of the TathÄgata. The feeling of the TathÄgata refers to the ultimate feeling, the absolute feeling.
Although the nature of feeling of sentient beings is impermanent, its continuity is uninterrupted. Therefore, one attains the permanent feeling of the TathÄgata.
It is like a person whose surname is KÄÅ›yapa. Although the person is impermanent, the surname is permanent, and it does not change for thousands of generations.
The Buddha-nature of sentient beings is also like this. For this reason, it is said that feeling is the Buddha-nature.'
Some also say:
'Thought is the Buddha-nature.
Why is it so?
Because of the causes and conditions of thought, one attains the true thought of the TathÄgata.

The thought of the TathÄgata is called the thought of no thought. The thought of no thought is neither the thought of sentient beings nor the thought of male and female, nor is it the thought of form, feeling, perception, formation, or consciousness, nor is it the thought of the annihilation of thought. Although the thought of sentient beings is impermanent, because the sequence of thoughts continues without interruption, one attains the thought of the TathÄgata's permanence.
Good man!
It is like the twelve links of dependent origination of sentient beings. Although sentient beings cease to exist, the links of dependent origination remain constant.
The Buddha-nature of sentient beings is also like this. For this reason, thought is said to be the Buddha-nature.'
There are also those who say:
'Action is the Buddha-nature.
Why is it so?
Because action is called life. Due to the causes and conditions of life, one attains the TathÄgata's eternal life.
Although the life span of sentient beings is impermanent, the continuity of life is uninterrupted, and thus one attains the TathÄgata's true and eternal life span.
Good sons!
It is like the twelve divisions of the scriptures. Although the listeners and expounders are impermanent, the scriptures remain forever unchanged.
The Buddha-nature of sentient beings is also like this. For this reason, it is said that action is the Buddha-nature.'
There are also those who say:
'Consciousness is the Buddha-nature.
Because of consciousness, one attains the TathÄgata's impartial mind.
Although the consciousness and mind of sentient beings are impermanent, the continuity of consciousness is uninterrupted, and thus one attains the TathÄgata's true and eternal mind.
It is like the heat of fire. Although fire is impermanent, heat is not impermanent.
The Buddha-nature of sentient beings is also like this. For this reason, it is said that consciousness is the Buddha-nature.'
There are also those who say:
'Apart from the aggregates, there is a self, and that self is the Buddha-nature.
Why is it so?
Because of me, I have attained the eight kinds of self-mastery of the TathÄgata.
Some non-Buddhists say that going, coming, seeing, hearing, sorrow, and joy are the self, and that the characteristics of this self are impermanent, but the self of the TathÄgata is truly permanent.
Good man!
Just as the aggregates, sense bases, and elements are impermanent, but their names are permanent, so is the Buddha-nature of sentient beings.
Good man!
Just as the blind people each describe the elephant, although they do not get the whole truth, it is not that they do not describe the elephant.
Those who speak of Buddha-nature are also like this. It is neither the six dharmas nor apart from the six dharmas.
Good man!
Therefore, I say that the Buddha-nature of sentient beings is neither form nor apart from form, up to neither self nor apart from self.
Good man!
Although some non-Buddhists speak of self, there is actually no self.
The self of sentient beings is precisely the five aggregates. Apart from the aggregates, there is no separate self.
Good man!
It is like a lotus flower composed of stem, leaves, pistils, and stamens, apart from which there is no other flower. The self of sentient beings is also like this.
Good man!
It is like a house composed of walls, beams, grass, and wood, apart from which there is no other house.
It is like a forest composed of khadga trees, pÄruá¹£aka trees, nyagrodha trees, and udumbara trees, apart from which there is no other forest.
It is like an army composed of chariots, elephants, horses, and infantry, apart from which there is no other army.
It is like a brocade composed of multicolored threads, apart from which there is no other brocade.
It is like a great assembly composed of the four castes, apart from which there is no other assembly.
The self of sentient beings is also like this, apart from the five aggregates there is no other self.
Good man!
The TathÄgata's permanence is called the self.
The TathÄgata's Dharma body is boundless and unobstructed, unborn and unceasing, attaining the eight liberations, this is called the self.
Sentient beings' true nature lacks this self and what belongs to the self, but because they will definitely attain the ultimate emptiness of ultimate truth, it is called buddha-nature.
Good son!
Great kindness and great compassion are called buddha-nature.
Why is it so?

Great kindness and great compassion always follow the bodhisattva like a shadow follows a form. All sentient beings will definitely attain great kindness and great compassion. Therefore, it is said that all sentient beings possess buddha-nature.
Great kindness and great compassion are called buddha-nature, and buddha-nature is called the TathÄgata.
Great joy and great equanimity are called buddha-nature.
Why is it so?
If bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas cannot relinquish the twenty-five existences, they cannot attain supreme, perfect enlightenment.
Because all sentient beings will definitely attain it, it is said that all sentient beings possess buddha-nature.
Great joy and great equanimity are precisely buddha-nature, and buddha-nature is precisely the TathÄgata.
Buddha-nature is called great faith and resolve.
Why is it so?
Because of faith and resolve, bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are able to perfect the pÄramitÄs of giving, morality, up to prajÃ±Ä.
Because all sentient beings will definitely attain great faith and resolve, it is said that all sentient beings possess buddha-nature.
Great faith and resolve is precisely buddha-nature, and buddha-nature is precisely the TathÄgata. Buddha-nature is called the stage of the only child.
Why is it so?
Because of the causal condition of the stage of the only child, bodhisattvas attain an attitude of equality towards all sentient beings.
Because all sentient beings will definitely attain the stage of the only child, it is said that all sentient beings possess buddha-nature.
The stage of the only child is precisely buddha-nature, and buddha-nature is precisely the TathÄgata.
Buddha-nature is called the fourth power.
Why is it so?
Because of the fourth power, the bodhisattva is able to teach and transform sentient beings.
All sentient beings will definitely attain the fourth power, and therefore it is said that all sentient beings have buddha-nature.
The fourth power is precisely buddha-nature, and buddha-nature is precisely the TathÄgata.
Buddha-nature is called the twelve links of dependent arising.
Why is it so?
Because of dependent arising, the TathÄgata abides eternally.
All sentient beings definitely have such twelve links of dependent arising, and therefore it is said that all sentient beings have buddha-nature.
The twelve links of dependent arising are precisely buddha-nature, and buddha-nature is precisely the TathÄgata.
Buddha-nature is called the four unobstructed eloquences.
Because of the four unobstructed abilities, the meaning of the letters is unobstructed. Because the meaning of the letters is unobstructed, one is able to transform sentient beings.
The four unobstructed abilities are precisely the buddha-nature. The buddha-nature is precisely the TathÄgata.

The buddha-nature is called the samÄdhi of the peak. By cultivating this samÄdhi of the peak, one is able to comprehensively encompass all the Buddha's teachings. Therefore, it is said that the samÄdhi of the peak is called the buddha-nature.
Bodhisattvas in the ten abodes cultivate this samÄdhi but have not yet perfected it. Although they see the buddha-nature, it is not clear.
Because all sentient beings will definitely attain it, it is said that all sentient beings have the buddha-nature.
Good man, because all sentient beings will definitely attain the various dharmas explained above, it is said that all sentient beings have the buddha-nature.
